timeline.message: Refactor commands using lombok
Merge branch 'dev' into shahzaibj/lombok
Remove nonnull annotations
Add expose annotations to command parameters
Add transient for command parameters where needed
Use lombok as compile time only
Remove disabling of lint for invalid package
Remove commented code
Add validate logic to silent token command parameters
Remove operation parameters
Add missing license
Remove broker operation parameters, add broker request type enum
Make parameter collections immutable by returning a clone

timeline.author: shahzaibj

timeline.message: Move extra scopes and extra qp to interactive parameters
Remove setting extra qp on silent parameters in broker adapters
Add equals and hash code annotation to all commands and parameter classes
Add back throttling to Command Dispatcher
Merge branch 'dev' into shahzaibj/lombok
Add lombok version to version file
Format code
Merge branch 'dev' into shahzaibj/lombok

timeline.bodyText: nit: add @ getter and remove getName()?
timeline.author: rpdome

replies.bodyText: We don't need to - as part of this change I am not removing existing getters and setters. This equals was only added as it was needed and wasn't there.

timeline.bodyText:
nit: moving file in the middle of the change makes it harder to review IMO. (i.e. git could get drunk like what we're seeing in this file)
Next time, let's move the files in a separate PR.
timeline.author: rpdome

replies.bodyText: Sure
replies.author: shahzaibj

timeline.bodyText: nit: what does this mean? can't find it in the document.
timeline.author: rpdome

replies.bodyText:
Expose is GSON annotation to indicate whether a field should be serialized/deserialized or not. https://www.javadoc.io/doc/com.google.code.gson/gson/2.6.2/com/google/gson/annotations/Expose.html
It doesn't have anything to do with Lombok and this annotation was already present in our code.
replies.author: shahzaibj

timeline.bodyText: nit: are we including the throttling work in this PR also? if yes, the title is sort of misleading.
timeline.author: rpdome

replies.bodyText: Yes, we are. I've updated the title.
replies.author: shahzaibj

timeline.author: rpdome
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -99,9 +106,9 @@ public BrokerRequest brokerRequestFromAcquireTokenParameters(@NonNull final Acqu
                         parameters.getExtraQueryStringParameters() != null ?
                                 QueryParamsAdapter._toJson(parameters.getExtraQueryStringParameters())
                                 : null
-                ).prompt(parameters.getOpenIdConnectPromptParameter().name())
+                ).prompt(parameters.getPrompt().name())
                 .claims(parameters.getClaimsRequestJson())
-                .forceRefresh(parameters.getForceRefresh())
+                .forceRefresh(false)

replies.bodyText: Interactive doesn't have anything like forceRefresh
replies.author: shahzaibj

replies.bodyText:
This would break claimsRequest flow. Before this change , forceRefresh was on OperationParameter here  and we set forceRefresh to true for interactive calls when claimsRequest is present here . This is done because, in broker we would attempt to silently get a token for interactive calls as well if we a matching account using PRT, FRT, and if claimsRequest is present we would need to skip cache and refresh the token.
So i think you should move back forceRefresh to base class and add the logic back
replies.author: kreedula

+

+import com.microsoft.identity.common.internal.commands.parameters.TokenCommandParameters;

+import com.microsoft.identity.common.internal.result.AcquireTokenResult;
+
+import java.util.List;
+
+import lombok.EqualsAndHashCode;
+
+@EqualsAndHashCode(callSuper = true)
+public abstract class TokenCommand extends BaseCommand<AcquireTokenResult> {

replies.bodyText: It has an abstract method, and primarily meant as a base abstract command for any type of Token Command. Other token commands can just extend this.
replies.author: shahzaibj

timeline.bodyText:
This would break claimsRequest flow. Before this change , forceRefresh was on OperationParameter here  and we set forceRefresh to true for interactive calls when claimsRequest is present here . This is done because, in broker we would attempt to silently get a token for interactive calls as well if we a matching account using PRT, FRT, and if claimsRequest is present we would need to skip cache and refresh the token.
So i think you should move back forceRefresh to base class and add the logic back
timeline.author: kreedula
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -99,9 +106,9 @@ public BrokerRequest brokerRequestFromAcquireTokenParameters(@NonNull final Acqu
                         parameters.getExtraQueryStringParameters() != null ?
                                 QueryParamsAdapter._toJson(parameters.getExtraQueryStringParameters())
                                 : null
-                ).prompt(parameters.getOpenIdConnectPromptParameter().name())
+                ).prompt(parameters.getPrompt().name())
                 .claims(parameters.getClaimsRequestJson())
-                .forceRefresh(parameters.getForceRefresh())
+                .forceRefresh(false)

replies.bodyText: @kreedula forceRefresh was indeed set on base class operation parameters but I believe it was never used in any interactive flow and hence I removed it and put it only on silent. Can you share the code snippet where this value is actually being used during an interactive call?
replies.author: shahzaibj

replies.bodyText: Okay, I see so it seems it was never used on the OperationParameters but we need it on the BrokerRequest object to decide if we need to skip cache or not.
replies.author: shahzaibj

replies.bodyText: @kreedula I don't think I need to put them on base command parameter class in that case. I think I can just do this logic here at the adapter level and set the value of forceRefresh on BrokerRequest based on that.
replies.author: shahzaibj

replies.bodyText: It should work with the current implementation, as we unpack the BrokerRequest twice , once here   and the other one to convert to BrokerAcquireTokenParameters. I would like to make some changes to avoid unpacking BrokerRequest twice especially with compressed payloads, have a work item for it. So it should be on TokenCommandParameters so that when we transform BrokerRequest to BrokerAcquireTokenCommandParameters , we would have the value to set and get
replies.author: kreedula

replies.bodyText: @kreedula That doesn't make sense to me. All you need is for forceRefresh to be available on BrokerRequest regardless of how many times we unpack it. Why do you need it on TokenCommandParameters? When we skip cache in broker, then we create silent token command parameters and not interactive so you shouldn't need it to be on either interactive parameters or the base class. Would there be a case where we would need forceRefresh to live on interactive parameters? Am i missing something here?
replies.author: shahzaibj

replies.bodyText: let's chat offline, so we can resolve this faster
replies.author: kreedula

replies.bodyText: Resolved offline, consensus is to forceRefresh to BrokerRequest based on claimsRequest  and leave it out of TokenCommandParameters
replies.author: kreedula

replies.bodyText:
Per second discussion decided to go with @kreedula suggestion to put force refresh on base token command parameters as we would need to send it to broker request based on the value of Claims Request passed in by the developer and not the merged claims request as that could contain client capabilities.
Addressed it in common here: d567411
MSAL here: AzureAD/microsoft-authentication-library-for-android@69984b2
Added back tests here: AzureAD/microsoft-authentication-library-for-android@13a7dae
replies.author: shahzaibj

timeline.message: Put force refresh on base token command parameters
